turns.speaker: THE HOTEL MANAGER'S VOICE
turns.text: I think I need to call the police. He won't respond...

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: No, no. Don't call the police!  Just tell him I'm on the phone with you... My name is Lowell Bergman... Just tell him that.

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: Did he hear you?

turns.speaker: THE HOTEL MANAGER'S VOICE
turns.text: You're breaking up. I can't hear you.

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: What about now?

turns.speaker: THE HOTEL MANAGER'S VOICE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: Hello, can you hear me now?

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: What's happening?!

turns.speaker: THE HOTEL MANAGER'S VOICE
turns.text: He doesn't seem to be listening...

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: Alright, now listen to me. I want you -- I want you to tell him, in these words: get on the fucking phone...!

turns.speaker: THE HOTEL MANAGER'S VOICE
turns.text: I can't say that!

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: No, you can.  Tell him to get on the fucking phone!

turns.speaker: LOWELL'S VOICE
turns.text: Just give me an example...

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: For example. James Burke, the CEO of Johnson & Johnson... when he found out that some lunatic had put poison in Tylenol bottles, he didn't argue with the FDA... He didn't even wait for the FDA to tell him. He just pulled Tylenol off every shelf of every store right across America. Instantly. And then he developed the safety cap... Because, look, as a CEO, sure, he's gotta be a great businessman, right? But he's also a man of science. He's not going to allow his company... to put on the shelf... a product that might hurt people.  Not like the Seven Dwarfs...

turns.speaker: LOWELL'S VOICE
turns.text: We have a couple. One's hers, one's mine. Everybody uses a different name.  Modern marriage.  How's Liane?

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: She's okay.

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: Hold on a minute, Lowell...  ...somebody... may be following me. I don't know. They came on the property...

turns.speaker: LOWELL'S VOICE
turns.text: What do you mean followed you? Did you call the police?

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: I don't want to be paranoid... I mean, maybe it's a game. Some kind of mind game.

turns.speaker: LOWELL'S VOICE
turns.text: Well, what do you really think, though?

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: I don't know what the fuck I really think! Are they doing it? Is some crank doing it? Are they doing it to make me feel paranoid? Are they doing it for real and don't give a shit what I think? I don't know! I don't fucking know.

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: Well, no, look... I mean, there was a footprint. Forget it. It's probably not important at all.  You know, I got a job now. I'm teaching high school. Japanese and Chemistry.  So, what were you calling about?

turns.speaker: LOWELL'S VOICE
turns.text: You called me.

turns.speaker: LOWELL'S VOICE
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: Someone put a bullet in my mailbox.

turns.speaker: LOWELL'S VOICE
turns.text: I heard you. But I got to arrange a legal defense first. I got to get you to testify in court, get it on public record.

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: Then hold it off the air until you got that. But I want to go to New York. And I want to go on the record. Right now!

turns.speaker: LOWELL'S VOICE
turns.text: Jeffrey, how are you? How's the family, okay?

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: There is -- there is no family.

turns.speaker: LOWELL'S VOICE
turns.text: What do you mean there is no family?

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: Liane has filed for divorce...

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: And, so, I moved out... I see the girls a couple of days a week...

turns.speaker: LOWELL'S VOICE
turns.text: Where you staying now?

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: Our favorite hotel, honey... I checked into Room 930. Odd choice? Huh?

turns.speaker: RICHARD SCRUGGS
turns.text: Jeff Wigand, Michael Moore.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL MOORE
turns.text: Good to meet you, Dr. Wigand.

turns.speaker: RICHARD SCRUGGS
turns.text: Mike's our Attorney General down here.  I was just explaining to Jeff, they got a Kentucky court to issue a gag order to stop his deposition today.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL MOORE
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: RICHARD SCRUGGS
turns.text: Now, they tried to get the Mississippi Court to honor it, but the judge threw it out...  However, for you, there is a more perilous effect to the Kentucky gag order...

turns.speaker: MICHAEL MOORE
turns.text: Dr. Wigand, you do understand what could happen, don't you?

turns.speaker: MIKE WALLACE
turns.text: You heard Mr. Sandefur say before Congress that he believed nicotine was not addictive...?

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: ...I believe Mr. Sandefur perjured himself because I watched those testimonies very carefully.

turns.speaker: MIKE WALLACE
turns.text: All of us did. There was this whole line of people... whole line of CEOs up there all swearing.

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: Part of the reason I'm here is I felt that their representation clearly misstated, at least within Brown & Williamson's representation, clearly misstated... what is common language within the company... we are in the nicotine delivery business.

turns.speaker: MIKE WALLACE
turns.text: And that's what cigarettes are for...?

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: A delivery device for nicotine.

turns.speaker: MIKE WALLACE
turns.text: A delivery device for nicotine. Put it in your mouth, light it up, and you're gonna get your fix...

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: You're gonna get your fix...

turns.speaker: MIKE WALLACE
turns.text: You're saying that Brown & Williamson manipulates and adjusts the nicotine fix, not by artificially adding nicotine, but by enhancing the effect of nicotine through the use of chemical elements such as ammonia...

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: The process is known as "impact boosting..." While not spiking nicotine, they clearly manipulate it. There's extensive use of this technology, know as "ammonia chemistry." It allows for the nicotine to be more rapidly absorbed in the lung and therefore affect the brain and central nervous system.

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: The straw that broke the camel's back for me and really put me in trouble with Sandefur was a compound called "coumarin." When I came on board at B&W, they had tried to transition from coumarin to a similar flavor that would give the same taste, and had been unsuccessful. I wanted it out immediately. I was told that it would affect sales, so I should mind my own business. I constructed a memo to Mr. Sandefur indicating I could not in conscience continue with coumarin in a product that we now knew, we had documentation, was similar to coumadin, a lung-specific carcinogen...

turns.speaker: MIKE WALLACE
turns.text: And you sent the document forward to Sandefur?

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: I sent the document forward to Sandefur. I was told that we would continue to work on a substitute, we weren't going to remove it as it would impact sales, and that that was his decision.

turns.speaker: MIKE WALLACE
turns.text: In other words, you were charging Sandefur and Brown & Williamson with ignoring health considerations consciously...

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: Most certainly.

turns.speaker: MIKE WALLACE
turns.text: And on March 24, Thomas Sandefur, CEO of Brown & Williamson had you fired. And the reason he gave you?

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: Poor communication skills.

turns.speaker: MIKE WALLACE
turns.text: And, do you wish you hadn't come forward? You wish you hadn't blown the whistle?

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: Yeah, there are times I wish I hadn't done it. There are times I feel compelled to do it. If you asked me would I do it again? Do I think it's worth it? Yeah, I think it's worth it.

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: "I would bet on it."

turns.speaker: MIKE WALLACE
turns.text: "The former executive has reason to bet on being sued, for major cigarette manufacturers..."

turns.speaker: MIKE WALLACE
turns.text: "You wish you hadn't blown the whistle?"

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: "There are times... I wish I hadn't done it. But there are times that I feel compelled to do it..." "I've -- if you asked me if I would do it again or if it's -- do I think it's worth it. Yeah. I think it's worth it."

turns.speaker: TOBACCO LAWYER
turns.text: Object to the form of the question!

turns.speaker: MOTLEY
turns.text: It acts as a drug on the body?

turns.speaker: TOBACCO LAWYER
turns.text: Object to the form!

turns.speaker: MOTLEY
turns.text: It acts as a...

turns.speaker: TOBACCO LAWYER
turns.text: Object!

turns.speaker: MOTLEY
turns.text: There an echo in here? Your objection's been recorded. She typed it into her little machine over there. It's on the record. So now I'll proceed with my deposition of my witness. Does it act as a drug?

turns.speaker: TOBACCO LAWYER
turns.text: Dr. Wigand. I am instructing you...  ...not to answer that question in accordance to the terms of the contractual obligations undertaken by you not to disclose any information about your work at the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Company. And in accordance with the force and effect of the temporary restraining order that has been entered against you to by the court in the State of Kentucky! That means you don't talk!  Mr. Motley, we have rights, here...

turns.speaker: MOTLEY
turns.text: Oh, you got rights and lefts! Ups and downs and middles! So what?! You don't get to instruct anything around here! This is not North Carolina, not South Carolina nor Kentucky. This is the sovereign State of Mississippi's proceeding. Wipe that smirk off your face! Dr. Wigand's deposition will be part of this record. And I'm going to take my witness' testimony! Whether the hell you like it or not!  Answer the question, Dr...

turns.speaker: RICHARD SCRUGGS
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: Mr. Scruggs, Jeff Wigand. Lowell Bergman said I should give you a call...

turns.speaker: RICHARD SCRUGGS
turns.text: My co-counsel, Ron Motley, and I have filed a lawsuit against the tobacco industry on behalf of the State of Mississippi to get the state reimbursed Medicaid costs for treating people with smoking-related illness.  If you'd be interested in talking to us, we'd certainly like to talk to you...

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: When should we do this?

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: Jail?

turns.speaker: RICHARD SCRUGGS
turns.text: Possibly, yes. That is one of the possible consequences of your testifying here today. That's right...

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: How does one... "go... to... jail?" What does my family do? Go on welfare? If my wife has to work? Who's going to look after the kids? Put food on the table? My children need me. If I'm not teaching... there's no medical... no medical... even on co- pay, that's like... Tuition...

turns.speaker: THOMAS SANDEFUR
turns.text: Jeff's a premiere golfer... What are you, a two handicap?

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: Seven...

turns.speaker: THOMAS SANDEFUR
turns.text: And, he gets out there and he has five strokes on us. He has more concentration than anybody I've ever met. It's spooky how he can concentrate.

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: I'd rather play than talk about it.  What did you want to see me about? I don't like being back here.

turns.speaker: THOMAS SANDEFUR
turns.text: Jeffrey says exactly what's on his mind. Most people consider what they're saying... social skills... Jeffrey just charges right ahead.  Now, I know you understood the nature of the confidentiality portion of your severance agreement with Brown & Williamson, Jeff...

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: Chapter and verse.

turns.speaker: THOMAS SANDEFUR
turns.text: Yeah, I know you do...  You know, I came up through sales. One of the reasons I was a great salesman, was I never made a promise I couldn't keep.  I knew that if I ever broke my promise I'd suffer the consequence...

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: Is that a threat?

turns.speaker: THOMAS SANDEFUR
turns.text: ...we worked together for, what was it, three years...? Now, the work we did here is confidential, not for public scrutiny... any more than are one's family matters...

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: You threatening my family, now, too?

turns.speaker: THOMAS SANDEFUR
turns.text: Now, don't be paranoid, Jeff.  About the direction of research here, we may have had our differences of opinion...

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: "Research..."  You declare, as a badge of honor, you don't even know what makes water boil...

turns.speaker: THOMAS SANDEFUR
turns.text: That's why we hire scientists...

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: Okay.  I don't believe you can maintain corporate integrity without confidentiality agreements. I was paid well for my work. The health and welfare benefits are good. The severance package is fair. I have no intention of violating my confidentiality agreement and disclosing that which I said I wouldn't.

turns.speaker: THOMAS SANDEFUR
turns.text: I appreciate all that, Jeff. But, upon reflection... we've decided to expand our zone of comfort with you.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Yes. Your husband did show remarkable foresight in taking those pictures. And, yes, absent a swimming pool, the presence of the pool man would appear to be suspicious. But Bonnie, who is the real victim here? Let me suggest the following. Your husband, who on a prior occasion slapped you -- beat you --

turns.speaker: BONNIE
turns.text: Well, I wouldn't say --

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Your husband, who has beaten you -- repeatedly --

turns.speaker: BONNIE
turns.text: He --

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Please -- was at the time brandishing your firearm, trying in his rage to shoot an acquaintance -- friend of long standing --

turns.speaker: BONNIE
turns.text: They hate each other --

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: So he says now! But if not for your cool headed intervention, his tantrum might have ended this schmoe's life and ruined his own... As for the sexual indiscretion which he imagined had taken place, wasn't it in fact he who had been sleeping with the pool man?

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Miles, how nice of you to see us -- may I introduce Howard D. Doyle of Doyle Oil.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: I told you we know each other, baby. Mr. Massey represented my ex-brother- in law. Martin Reiser?

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Yeah. I know. Leather would be more practical, but whatcha gonna do?

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Miles, I know you're busy and that you charge by the hour so I'll come to the point. Howard and I are planning to marry.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Sixteen years? Howard Jr. is fourteen and Mandy must be what -- twelve?

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Here. Got pictures.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Honey, I don't think this is really relevant to...

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: ...and one day, this sweet girl calls me, asks me to lunch. Just a shoulder to cry on deal. One thing leads to another and before I know it --

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: -- we realized we'd always been very attracted to one another.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Baby. You are so HOT!

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Howard!

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: As you are well aware, my previous marriage ended with an unjustified strain on my reputation My motives were questioned. I was slandered in court.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: You did good, Massey!

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Therefore in an effort to remove any trace of suspicion from my sweet Howard -- I wish to execute a pre- nuptial agreement.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: And -- there's no talking her out of it. Believe me, I've tried.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: They say the Massey pre-nup has never been penetrated.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: She said "penetrate." Heh heh heh.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Course I can't do much "wriggling" if you tie me up like that again. Massey -- this is one bad bad little girl.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: We'd better go before we get thrown out.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Oh. Right. Won't you have a seat?

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: After you, Doll.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: And how is Mrs. Reiser?

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Few suicide attempts, little inpatient stint. Naturally, she misses her kids. Six weekends a year and alternate Yom Kippurs seemed harsh to us but -- hey -- all's fair. Anyhoo, she lives with a "nurse," takes her meds and goes to occupational therapy at a local sheltered workshop.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: So she's uh, flourishing?

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: She makes felt wallets. Got one right here.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Muh -- Well, uh -- Huh?

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Yep. My divorce just came through. Shoulda called you. Coulda cut a better deal! My wife still has health insurance and gets to see the children. But, I don't know. Guess I'm just a softie. After all Amanda and me were together for -- what -- you'd know better than me, Marylin. She was your best friend.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: I... uh guess congratulations are in order.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Well -- Marylin and Rex broke up and...

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: I had no idea until after, but --

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: What a touching story.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: You know, Miles, after my wife -- wife's mastectomy -- things were never the same. This might sound cold, well, maybe not to you, Massey, but...  I like my women with two boobs.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Harvard? Whoa, Daddy!

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: I just want to make sure that you both --

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: -- understand what you're asking for here. The Massey pre-nup provides that in the event of a dissolution of the marriage for any reason, both parties shall leave it with whatever they brought in, and earned during. No one can profit from the marriage. The pre-nup protects the wealthier party.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Well -- at the moment, that'd be me.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: And without it, that party is exposed -- a sitting duck. No wriggle room.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: A Wriggle Room! Maybe we should put that in the Malibu house. Screw the screening room!

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: -- and we are sure...

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Excuse me, Mr. Doyle, if I could just borrow your charming fiancee for a moment.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: What part?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: I'd just like to have a word with her.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Why not? I'm going to have her for a lifetime.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: I am here representing Mr. Dumbarton, on a... matter of some delicacy.

turns.speaker: GANGSTER
turns.text: Who's the pigeon?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Excuse me?

turns.speaker: GANGSTER
turns.text: Who do you want me to kill?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Well -- I, uh, that is to say Mr. Dumbarton -- would like you to uh, neutralize a, uh, business associate by the name of Marylin Rexroth Doyle Massey uh Dumbart -- uh, Massey.

turns.speaker: GANGSTER
turns.text: Is that... one person?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Here's her picture...

turns.speaker: GANGSTER
turns.text: You're in a rush.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Mr. Dumbarton is, yes.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Whoever sent you, I'll pay double.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Mr. Dumbarton.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Is this Mr. Dumbarton?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: No...

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: That's his lawyer.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Triple!

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Who's the pigeon?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: You're calling me a pestilence? That's a hoot!

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: I'm sorry. That was unkind and -- but, we changed our minds.  Did you really mean what you said on the phone. It wasn't because you found out about Rex?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Lemme tell you something. You are the pestilence. I'm the exterminator.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Oh Joe, be happy for us. I'll pay you the twenty thousand.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Well, actually, all whores worship the dollar, if you want to get technical.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Shut up. I was a lawyer. Just like you. And my clients? Whores just like you.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: Objection, your honor!

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Grounds?

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: Uh... poetry recitation.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Who's next, Mrs. Rabinow.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: We rest, Your Honor.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Mr. Massey?

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: Objection, Your Honor. This isn't about Mrs. Rexroth's filial obligations.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Sustained.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: She got absolutely nothing. Zero. Zip.

turns.speaker: KENNETH
turns.text: So. I won't be seeing her? Your clients usually visit me after the settlement.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Not this one. Not unless her HMO covers plastic surgery, which, incidentally, she does not need.

turns.speaker: KENNETH
turns.text: Everyone needs plastic surgery. You need it.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: I don't need it.

turns.speaker: KENNETH
turns.text: You want Botox?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: What the hell is Botox?

turns.speaker: KENNETH
turns.text: It's a form of botulism. I just inject it into your forehead, and it paralyzes your eyebrows so you can't raise them...

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Why in God's name would I want...?

turns.speaker: KENNETH
turns.text: No frown lines.  New watch?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: It's a LeCoultre Revers. You can flip the face, and set it for two time zones.

turns.speaker: KENNETH
turns.text: Why would you need two time zones? You never leave Beverly Hills.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: It was a gift from a client.

turns.speaker: KENNETH
turns.text: Set one side for Bel Air.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Botox. Christ. We had aspirations when we were in college.

turns.speaker: KENNETH
turns.text: We did not.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: You were going to be a Cardiac Surgeon. I was going to clerk for the Supreme Court.

turns.speaker: KENNETH
turns.text: I was going to play golf. You were going to have Asian girlfriends.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Denial is not a river in Egypt.

turns.speaker: KENNETH
turns.text: You're in check.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: I should be in therapy.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Do you think I'm going to end up like Herb Myerson, with a colostomy bag instead of a family?

turns.speaker: KENNETH
turns.text: Got any symptoms?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Yes. The inability to experience pleasure.

turns.speaker: KENNETH
turns.text: Oh. That.  Don't waste time with your queen.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: KENNETH
turns.text: The Center Counter Defense. The thing is not to move your queen too early.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: She can't really love that idiot, can she?

turns.speaker: KENNETH
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Marylin Rexroth. She came into my office and signed a pre-nup with Howard Doyle.

turns.speaker: KENNETH
turns.text: Doyle Oil?  A Massey Pre-nup?  She loves him.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: He's the wrong man.

turns.speaker: KENNETH
turns.text: Miles! Don't waste time with someone else's queen, either.

turns.speaker: KENNETH
turns.text: I'm happy for you, pal.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Thanks, buddy.

turns.speaker: KENNETH
turns.text: Is she Asian?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Asian? No.

turns.speaker: KENNETH
turns.text: Well... I'm still...

turns.speaker: KENNETH
turns.text: I have it.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: You have the pre-nup?

turns.speaker: KENNETH
turns.text: No. I have the ring. Was I supposed to have a pre-nup?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: No. You have the ring. Wrigley has the pre-nup.

turns.speaker: KENNETH
turns.text: Oh. I thought maybe --  Gee!

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: They won't get a conviction. The husband called it in as a suicide. The forensic guys weren't thinking murder. I'm sure some of the evidence was compromised.

turns.speaker: KENNETH
turns.text: It's your move, Miles.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: I already made my move, Kenneth.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: My God.

turns.speaker: KENNETH
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: That was Marvin Untermeyer.

turns.speaker: KENNETH
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: He was Rex Rexroth's personal attorney.

turns.speaker: KENNETH
turns.text: What do you mean, was.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Rex just had a massive coronary. In the middle of a business meeting. He's dead.

turns.speaker: KENNETH
turns.text: I'm sorry to hear that. But you weren't close, were you?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Marvin says that Rex's will is four years old. He never redrafted it.

turns.speaker: KENNETH
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: She's rich. We're still married. We have no pre-nup.

turns.speaker: KENNETH
turns.text: So, that's good, right?

turns.speaker: KENNETH
turns.text: Who was that?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: That was -- oh, shit. What if he's on his way over there?

turns.speaker: KENNETH
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Marylin! What have I done?

turns.speaker: KENNETH
turns.text: I don't know, but don't call me Marylin.

turns.speaker: LAWYER
turns.text: Mrs. Guttman, you have testified that you were your husband's sexual slave for thirty-six years, ever since you were married --

turns.speaker: WITNESS
turns.text: Except for two years when he was in the Navy, in Korea.

turns.speaker: LAWYER
turns.text: Prior to your marriage, what was your profession?

turns.speaker: WITNESS
turns.text: I was a hostess. For Trans-World Airlines.

turns.speaker: LAWYER
turns.text: What is your husband's profession?

turns.speaker: WITNESS
turns.text: He manufactures staples and industrial brad-tacks. He's very successful.

turns.speaker: RAMONA
turns.text: So who'd you hire?

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Ruth Rabino.

turns.speaker: RAMONA
turns.text: You should have tried to get pregnant Marylin -- solidify your position.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: RAMONA
turns.text: You like kids.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: I can't have a baby with a man I don't love... And I can't submit a child to divorce.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: It was like that scene in The Godfather. Frankie Pentangeli is called to testify against the Family. And he's in court, and he looks into the spectators gallery, and sees his Brother. They brought the brother from Sicily. And Frankie can't say a word. He can't testify. That's what it was like seeing Pat in there. I couldn't even have Ruth cross examine her.

turns.speaker: RAMONA
turns.text: Why do you think she did it?

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Maybe she wanted a free trip to LA. Maybe they offered her money. Massey is very seductive. Who knows.

turns.speaker: RAMONA
turns.text: Maybe they put a horse head in her bed?

turns.speaker: RAMONA
turns.text: I begged you to have a baby!

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: In the Godfather, after the courtroom scene, Frankie Pentangeli opens his veins in the bathtub.

turns.speaker: RAMONA
turns.text: You're vulnerable.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: It's about time.

turns.speaker: RAMONA
turns.text: You said 'yes' didn't you?

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: I said yes.

turns.speaker: RAMONA
turns.text: Is Tong older than Ming?

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: I think Ming is older than Tong.  What is this?

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Well. He said to "make the house mine."

turns.speaker: RAMONA
turns.text: Oh boy. If he only knew.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Yeah. I guess. You know --

turns.speaker: RAMONA
turns.text: It sounded like a bell.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: I'll be right back.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: -- Ruth Rabinow, this is Rex Rexroth. And you must be Mrs. Rexroth.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: And you must be Mr. Massey.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: How nice.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Positano is beautiful. Remember when we were there, Rex? We stayed in the Santo Pietro? That hotel on the cliff?

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: These are yours.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Not according to Mrs. Rabinow.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: I assume this is on Rex?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Isn't everything?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Your husband told me you were beautiful, but I was unprepared.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: "Dismiss your vows, your feigned tears, your flattery, for where a heart is hard, they make no battery."

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Do you have a hard heart, Marylin.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Did you see the tape?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Not yet.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: See the tape. Then we can discuss my heart.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Tell me Mr. Massey. What was your performance about this afternoon?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: What does your lawyer think?

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Ruth says you've been too successful, that you're bored, complacent, and you're on your way down.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: But you don't agree?

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: How do you know?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Why would you be here?

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: I told you. I was hungry.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: I'll have the tournedos of beef. And the lady will have the same?  I assume you're a carnivore.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: I know you do.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: "Who ever lov'd that lov'd not at first sight?"

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: You didn't ask me here to pick me up. You could get in trouble for that.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Not really. You're not my client. Freedom of association. Big issue with the First Amendment fans. Want to go to Hawaii for the weekend?

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Have you ever been married, Miles?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: You don't believe in it.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: As a matter of fact, I'm a huge fan.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: You just haven't met the right person.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: No. I haven't. Have you?

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: All right, Miles. Let me tell you everything you THINK you know. I was married to Rex for a long time. I was an excellent wife, a partner, a lover, a hostess and a friend. There was only one thing I did wrong during the five years we were together. I got five years older. Think he should be able to ditch me for that?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: He wants a reconciliation.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: See the tape. Then we can discuss reconciliation. Rex screwed up and I nailed his ass. Now I'm going to have it mounted and have my girlfriends over to throw darts at it. Then I'm getting on with my life. That's all I'm after.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Gotcha.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: What is it you're after, Miles?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Oh, I'm a lot like you -- just looking for an ass to mount.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Well, don't look at mine!

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Yes. I loved my husband, Rex.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: And you've always loved him?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: And you hoped to spend the rest of your life with him?

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Yes. Why is that so difficult for you to understand?

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: He'll regret this.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Have you ever met Mr. Rexroth?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Oh, for the love of...

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: That is true, isn't it Miles? Your pre-nup is the best there is?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: That is correct. Not to blow my own horn, but they devote an entire semester to it at Harvard Law.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: -- we are both sure that's what we want?

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Absolutely.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Getting married.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: To him? He's a sick freak.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: He's passionate.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Passionate! He's a pervert. He should have to register when he moves.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: All girls enjoy a little rough trade from time to time.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Marylin! Listen to me.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: No. You listen to me.  You busted me, Miles. You left me with nothing! What did you expect me to do? Get a degree in counseling? Write a book about table linen? Because that's what wives do when they get dumped, and frankly, I'm not quite ready for that.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: But why him?

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: We told you. We realized we've always been in love.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: The Massey pre-nup has never been pene -- successfully challenged.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: So I hear. Is that all?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: No, that's not all.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: I'd like to offer my congratulations. That was a beautiful gesture of Howard's.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Howard is a beautiful person.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Yes. He's a diamond in the rough. And I have a feeling that someday soon you'll be taking that diamond and leaving the rough.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Miles. Miles. Miles.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: I am thrilled for you, but tell me this... How'd you get Howard to do it? I've addressed enough juries to appreciate the power of suggestion, but it seemed like he thought it was his own idea.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: It was his idea. It was a gesture of love and trust. Be happy for me, Miles.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Well, when this goes south -- promise you'll have dinner with me?

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Have you tried the duck?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: I figure a couple of months. That's how long it should take for the ink on the settlement to dry.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: It has bones. Be sure to swallow one.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Although knowing you as I do -- there will be no settlement. This time it will be complete and total annihilation.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: To victory.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: I don't feel victorious Miles. I feel betrayed, abandoned and humiliated. I have pictures of him with another woman...

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: More pictures? My God, Marylin. You can open an erotic art gallery.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Did you invite me here to score some cheap laughs.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: No. Just to comfort you, and appreciate you --

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: You really think I engineered the whole thing. You think the marriage and the divorce was part of some scheme. You came here to celebrate because you think I'm without morality or soul. You --  sound like my mother.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Hello?

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Miles?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Yes? Marylin?

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: You're right about me. I am worthless. I am nothing. I don't deserve to live.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Marylin? When did I say...?

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: I don't blame them for betraying me. I don't blame Rex, or Howard or my father. You see, Miles, I'm going to tell you something about me. Something you may or may not know. I suck!

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Screw you, asswipe!

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Marylin? Forgive me but are you -- drunk?

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: A little.  You get out of the car. That's right, Fuctard. I'm talkin' to you!

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: You shouldn't be driving. Where are you?

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: I'm on Sunset. Near the Beverly Hills hotel. Wanna meet me for a drink in the Polo...?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: I live right near there. The 800 Block of Maple. Come here. Marylin -- come here right now before -- just come here.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Okay. Should I stop at Starbucks and pick up a blended for --

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: No. Don't stop.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Okay Miles.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: You have a very nice home, Miles. Very inviting.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: You have wonderful art. I love that lithograph. Hockney?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Yes. I just got that, actually. It was a gift.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: From a -- girlfriend.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: No. No. I don't have a... no. It was from a client.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: No kidding. I'll bet you have some very grateful clients. What'd Rex buy you?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Rex sent me two humidors full of pre- Castro Cubans.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Is that you?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Me. Yes.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Oh. And that is -- mom?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Yeah. Mom. Mom and brother.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: You look like you were a very sensitive child. You have expressive eyes.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Hmmm...

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: And your mother was very beautiful. She must be proud of you.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: She never particularly cared for me.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: She didn't love you?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: No. She loved me. She would never not love her son. She just didn't... I wasn't her "type." She said I was a very, colicky baby. You know? Difficult. Not a good sleeper? Didn't eat well? We got off to a bad start, and she never seemed to recoup --

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: She held that against you?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Apparently she was very disappointed.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Boy. Boy, oh boy.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: And here I thought my mother was...

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Your mother was.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Oh right. You met Patricia.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: We're damaged goods.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: No, we're not!

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: We are, Miles. You know I'm right. There's something "off" about you and me Miles. And maybe it isn't because of these women -- maybe they were just extremely insightful and recognized our "deficiencies" very early on. Maybe...

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: That is bullshit! Mine is a bitch and yours is a psycho. I can't believe you're saying this, Marylin! There's nothing wrong with us. We're attractive and charismatic and successful and... I like us.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: I'm sorry Miles. You shouldn't listen to me. I'm sure you have a very fulfilling life. I'd better go. I'm depressing.

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Thank you for the coffee. It's very robust.

turns.speaker: MARYLIN
turns.text: Friends?

turns.speaker: MILES
turns.text: Don't go. Stay with me for a while.
